text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with farro with wild mushrooms
that's right I'm gonna show you a little
modern side dish magic with a very
ancient grain and I mean ancient or if
you wanted to tweet about this when it
first came out you would have had a
chiseled into a piece of stone which is
so much harder although you wouldn't had
a character limit but anyway this very
very old grain is easy to prepare
nutritious and very delicious so let me
show you how to put this together and
first up we're going to take care of our
wild mushrooms and for this I'm going to
use some dried porcini and you know it's
going to be expensive when you see
script on the label and price by the
pound this is very expensive but the
good news is you only need a tiny tiny
amount and all we need to do to prep
this is soak it in some warm water for
about 20-30 minutes until it's soft
enough to dice up so we'll just put that
in some warm water and we'll set that
aside until needed at that point we can
move on to our non wild mushrooms so
we're also going to use a little bit of
fresh mushroom here so I have some brown
cremini mushrooms and before we cut them
I'm going to take off the stem I just
think it looks a little nicer those tend
to be a little more fibrous but mostly
it's just aesthetics and what we want to
do here is just cube these up and to do
that all you have to do is slice it
three or four times this way and then
turn and then slice it three or four
times that way and if you do that you're
going to have some nicely uniform pieces
of mushroom check it out I don't think
people realize that good knife skills
have more to do geometry than they do
hand-eye coordination it's true and then
once those are cut let's head over to
the stove and we'll put a pan on
medium-high heat with a little bit of
olive oil in it and we'll toss in our
mushrooms along with a big pinch of salt
and what we want to do is cook these
until they have a little bit of color on
them and you know the deal with
mushrooms in these kind of recipes first
we make them wet then we make them dry
then we make them wet so first I salts
going to draw moisture out of the
mushroom it's going to get all kind of
wet and slimy but that's okay because
that moisture will evaporate and they
will start to saute in that oil and
pretty soon you'll have something that
looks like this and of course saute them
like this is what really brings out that
meaty mushroom flavor all right so
you're going to want to cook yours at
least this far and at this point we can
go ahead and add our dried porcini which
hopefully are no longer dry so we'll
fish those out of our water mine we're
in there about 20 minutes at this point
they should be soft enough to give a
rough chop to and if they're not let
them go a little longer but anyway we're
going to give those
and we'll toss those in with our fresh
mushrooms and we'll saute that for a few
minutes to kind of take a little bit of
that wetness out of the mushroom and I
believe our heats still on medium-high
but if you want to back it down a little
bit towards medium that's probably not a
bad idea so like I said we'll dump in
the porcini we'll cook that with our
regular mushrooms for a couple minutes
at which point we're gonna add a half a
diced onion and we will stir that in and
we will saute that for I don't know five
or six minutes until those onions turn
translucent and kind of get a little bit
golden and they should look something
like this at which point we will add
some minced garlic and we'll stir that
in and as usual I'm going to cook that
for about two minutes please do not
brown your garlic although there is a
lot of moisture in that pan so that's
probably not going to happen but just be
careful and once we've given that garlic
a little quick sizzle we can add the
star of the show the farro a beautiful
and like I said very ancient grain and
please make sure you're getting what's
called pearled farro and I'll explain
that on the blog but that's what you're
going to need for this recipe and of
course you've done this ahead of time
but what we want to do before we add
this to the pan is I like to give it a
rinse in cold water this brand I'm using
came from Tuscany so we'll give it a
quick wash just in case there's any
Tuscan dust then we'll let that drain
and we'll go ahead and dump that into
our pan because before we introduce any
liquid here I want to make sure all
those grains are coated with olive oil
kind of similar to a risotto technique
which this recipe is loosely based on so
stir that around until your Pharos
completely coated
at which point we're going add just 1
cup of chicken broth and what we want to
do is raise our heat up to high to bring
this up to a simmer I'm also going to
add a nice big pinch of salt here and
then here's the plan as soon as that
starts simmering we're going to back the
heat down to medium-low we're going to
cover it and we're going to cook that
covered until all that broth has been
absorbed which is probably going to take
about 10 minutes and what we should do
is give it a stir about halfway through
so I'm going to take off the lid to give
it a stir all right even it back out
we'll put the lid back on and cook it
until like I said all that broth has
been absorbed at which point it should
look something like this and then once
that's happened we'll add the rest of
the broth which is a couple cups and
we'll stir that in and then we're
basically going to sort of repeat the
process we'll raise our heat up to high
until it starts to simmer all right
we'll give it a stir and then once again
we'll back our heat down to medium-low
we'll cover that and we will cook it
covered on
'i'm low for 15 minutes and just like
before we'll take off the lid once in a
while and give it a stir and you can see
those grains are starting to swell up a

that stock so we'll put the lid back on
and like I said we're going to go for 15
minutes and at that point it should look
something like this
all right your mixture should still be
fairly wet at this point your farro
should just start to be getting tender
it won't be there yet but for the rest
of the cooking process we're gonna leave
the lid off and we're just going to keep
cooking and stirring until we've reached
our desired doneness and this is the
part of the recipe we call the
adjustment phase if your grain is
already cooked and the mixture has too
much moisture
turn up the heat dry it up a little bit
conversely if your farro is still too
firm and the mixture is getting too dry
add another splash of broth or stock
that is you cooking so I let mine go for
a few more minutes until it looked like
this which for me was absolutely perfect
not too dry not too wet those grains of
farro or tender but have a little bit of
chewiness to them and of course just
like if you're doing a pasta or rice
side dish you're the one that has to
decide how far to cook this like I said
I like mine tender but with a little bit
of chewiness to it other people like
there's very firm other people like
there is very soft so that is completely
up to you but once we have decided it's
just right let's turn our heat all the
way down to low and move to final

creme fraiche is a fermented cream so
it's going to provide a little acidity a
little Tang enos which i think works
really nice here so we'll stir that in
we can also do our final seasoning at

I think it's a nice touch but again
that's up to you you are the nero of
your farro
so i'm going to stir that in and then
transfer that into some kind of

then because I already had it out I

based side dish looks pretty impressive
so let's go ahead and dig in and if

it just has a very mild or
